title: Objects of British and European Royal Provenance to Be Auctioned at Christie’s
text:
Text size

Some £2 million (US$2.4 million) in historic furnishings and art objects, many of them with British and other European royal provenance or British country house connections, will be auctioned on Sept. 19 in London by Christie’s.

The lead lot of the 355-item sale— German artist’s Max Liebermann’s 1911 oil painting Corso auf dem monte Pincio, which was owned by the art dealer/publisher Paul Cassirer, is expected to bring £200,000 to £300,000, according to the auction catalog.

The paintings, ceramics, sculptures, tapestries, silver, and art works in Visions of Collecting: Royal and Aristocratic, An Important Private Collection were assembled over 30 years, Charles Cator, deputy chairman of Christie’s International, said in a statement announcing the sale.

Calling the collection “intriguing and diverse,” he said that “if there is one theme that stands out, the leitmotif linking all these objects together is provenance.”

In some cases, the objects span generations. The sale includes a pair of mahogany stools dating to 1780-95 that seated themselves in Britain’s George III’s Windsor Castle (estimated at £6,000 to £10,000); a Rundell, Bridge & Rundell bronze statuette of his eldest son, George IV, as an emperor (estimated at £15,000 to £25,000); and a portrait of Princess Sophie (estimated at £30,000 to £50,000) that was owned by the Princes of Hanover, descendants of his fifth son.

The Eglington Race-Cups, pair of George III silver-gilt cups and covers, Mark of William Burwash, London, 1817; estimate: £8,000-£12,000. Christie's

The royal treasures also include oval medallions of the Holy Roman Emperor and Empress—Marie Antoinette’s brother, Joseph I, and his wife, Wilhelmina Amalia of Brunswick Lüneburg —which are estimated at £15,000 to £25,000.

The Wettin Electors of Saxony are represented by a decorated armorial Meissen dish from Augustus III ’s coronation service (estimated at £8,000 to £12,000); and the Romanov czars of Russia by a bust of Empress Elizabeth Alekseevna (estimated at £15,000 to £25,000).

Britain’s great country houses also are a core of the collection. There’s a painting of Tottenham Park in Wiltshire (estimated at £30,000 to £50,000) and chairs from Ditchley, which in the 20 th century was the epitome of Anglo-American taste (estimated at £30,000 to £50,000).

Bidders also will have a chance to buy a pair of armchairs estimated at £15,000 to £25,000 and a sofa estimated at £10,000 to £15,000 that took up residence at Claremont, the 18 th -century Palladian mansion in Surrey where George IV’s only daughter, Princess Charlotte, lived.

A Queen Anne walnut wing armchair, early 18th century, estimate: £6,000-£10,000. Christie's

A pair of glass candelabra from the Duke of Newcastle’s Clumber Park, which was demolished in 1938 after a fire, are estimated at £40,000 to £60,000. A William IV antiquarian central open bookcase, from Ashdown House, a 17 th -century estate in Oxfordshire where “Winter Queen" Elizabeth of Bohemia stayed, is estimated at £30,000 to £50,000.

Other items include ceiling moldings and door cases from “the new drawing room” at the demolished Big House at Bowood, whose interiors were designed by Robert Adam; an 18 th -century pier mirror from Park House at Elmley Castle; and garden armchairs owned by Deborah, the Duchess of Devonshire.

Cator added that the past life of the objects in the Royal and Aristocratic collection, “who has owned and enjoyed them, the palaces, and great houses they have adorned, is all part of their story and their appeal—the romance of objects.”
